fields.description:
Having an empty string in fields that do not support {{null}} will cause indexing to fail, with the following exception:
Error reported:
{quote}
2011-02-15 14:58:05,359 ERROR [InitialPinger2 <Repository>] fisheye.app BaseRepositoryScanner-handleSlurpException - Problem processing revisions from repo <Repository> due to class org.hibernate.PropertyAccessException - Exception occurred inside setter of com.atlassian.fisheye.model.ChangesetComment.message
org.hibernate.PropertyAccessException: Exception occurred inside setter of com.atlassian.fisheye.model.ChangesetComment.message
.
.
Caused by: java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException
at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:57)
at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
.
.
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Changeset comment messages may not be null or empty
at com.cenqua.crucible.model.ModelUtils.ensureNotNullOrEmpty(ModelUtils.java:8)
at com.atlassian.fisheye.model.ChangesetComment.setMessage(ChangesetComment.java:71)
... 36 more
{quote}

The upgrade task is designed to take care of this, though in this case the check appears to have been missed.

Workaround:
# Shutdown Fisheye
# Backup your database
# Run the sql below on your Fisheye database:
{noformat}
update cru_changeset_comment set cru_message = ' ' where cru_message = ''
{noformat}
fields.summary: After 2.5 upgrade indexing stops with error "Changeset comment messages may not be null or empty"

fields.description:
Exception from [FSH-5283|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/FSH-5283]:

{noformat}
08:37:31 ERROR - org.hibernate.hql.ast.QuerySyntaxException: unexpected AST node:
query [select review from com.cenqua.crucible.model.Review review join review.project proj where () and ( (lower(review.name) like '%trm-34944%' or lower(review.description) like '%trm-34944%' or lower(proj.projKey) like '%trm-34944%' )) and review.stateName <> 'Dead'  order by review.id desc]
Feb 21, 2011 8:37:31 AM com.sun.jersey.server.impl.application.WebApplicationImpl onException
SEVERE: Internal server error
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at java.util.LinkedList.addAll(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.LinkedList.addAll(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.LinkedList.<init>(Unknown Source)
	at com.atlassian.crucible.spi.impl.DefaultSearchService.searchForReviews(DefaultSearchService.java:37)
{noformat}	

This is because of two problems:
- the HQL query is malformed because of the empty parenthesis in the {{where}} clause  ("{{where ()}}"):
{code:sql}
select review from com.cenqua.crucible.model.Review review join review.project proj where () and ( (lower(review.name) like '%trm-34944%' or lower(review.description) like '%trm-34944%' or lower(proj.projKey) like '%trm-34944%' )) and review.stateName <> 'Dead'  order by review.id desc
{code}
- any exception causes _DefaultReviewManager#searchReviewForTerms()_ to return a {{null}} instead of an empty collection (regression created in CRUC-3617)
fields.summary: NullPointerException in REST search reviews for terms (because of an invalid HQL query)

fields.description:
If you add someone to a review, Crucible checks whether the user has permission to be added but does not check whether the user has permission to see the underlying repository.

(Hopefully, there is a check on the author adding revisions to the review that at least they have permission to see those revisions!)

Thus someone can be added to a review and see the content of the files in the review.

More subtly, the same happens when a patch review anchors - the reviewers can see the full context of the files that have anchored, where the author may not be aware of this.

Potential solutions? A total rethink of permissions in FECru, with projects becoming the top-level items in FishEye Repositories becoming part of projects. Permissions all project based.


h3. Workaround

By default, Crucible project caches content of files added from Fisheye repository. You can disable this option in Administration > Projects > Edit project > 'Store the contents of files in reviews'. When disabled, Crucible will always call Fisheye to fetch file content when reviewing. During this fetch, repository permissions are respected.
fields.summary: Code reviews with cached content should respect current repository permissions

fields.description:

{noformat} So the pattern {{"]+class=\"errMsg\">(.+?)<\\/span>"}} (JiraIssueImpl.java:225) doesn't find it. We should change the Map containing regexes to contain a list of regexes, which would also simplify our treatment of keys for 4.1 vs later JIRA versions.

fields.description:
There is currently no limit to the size of Crucible reviews that can be created.  Because of this, someone can create a MASSIVE review with lots of files (or large files) that can do one of two things:
* Impact the performance of Crucible - the review takes a long time to load and can be slow on the client-side.
* Cause issues indexing data.  A large review can cause a repository to get stuck on "Indexing Review Data" for a long time.

We should provide administrators the ability to limit review size by either # of files or size of content.
fields.summary: Add Ability to Limit Number and/or Size of Crucible Reviews

fields.description:
Many customers have reported that Fisheye/Crucible can get stuck on "Indexing Review Data" for a repository.  In most cases, the indexing isn't stuck but can take a long time due to a large Crucible review that was created.

We should improve DEBUG logging in this case so we can determine exactly what Reviews are being indexed and why it may be taking so long.
fields.summary: Better DEBUG Logging when "Indexing Review Data"

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Configure an Applinks for a fisheye instance in JIRA.
2. Goto Fisheye configuration link and click "Refresh Cache", which shows user a link to "Login & Approve ".
3. Click on "Login and approve".

Result:
1. Its failing with error "HTTP Status 404 - /secure/admin/%7B0%7D"
fields.summary: "Login & Approve " link is pointing to the wrong URL

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Login as JIRA as sysadmin.
2. Click on Admin->Fisheye configuration and create a app links for a Fisheye instance.
3. As user doesn't have admin permission on the fisheye URL, user creates a one way link.
4. Setup basic access. Now from the project page select a project and click on "Select Path" to set a Repository Path.
5. Select a Repository and click "Submit".

Result:
1. JIRA fails with stack trace.
fields.summary: Trying to add a repository for a project with "basic access" configured in App links throw stacktrace

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Login to JIRA as sysadmin
2. Click Admin->Fisheye Configuration.
3. There is link to "continue with the setup process" if you have already an atlaseye setup. Click on that.

Result:
1. It take user to "App links" page without any clue what we need to do next. From user point of view its very unfriendly UI.
fields.summary: Fisheye configuration page in JIRA doesn't give user any information about setup process

fields.description:
Required fields in task creation might prevent the successful creation of a task from Crucible. See CRC-2310.

Referenced by support to this thread: http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=48971

It might be the answer but for me is not an option. There are fields marked as required because they need to be. Making them optional would break my workflow (missing required data).
fields.summary: Customise which fields are set during subtask creation

fields.description: If a Perforce command produces no output on standard output, we throw an NPE. This masks anything the command produced on standard error.
fields.summary: Empty responses from p4 commands cause NullPointerException

fields.description:
The com.sun.jna library is now required always, not only when the built-in SvnKit is used


If you have set a different subversion client by setting one of the JAR or Dynamic Library settings in Administration, Server Settings, Subversion client, then the jna jar is not added to the classpath, and startup will fail.
fields.summary: java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/tigris/subversion/javahl/SVNClient thrown on startup

fields.description:
Any idea why that would happen?  restart doesn't help and it tends to only happen with some repo setups (even though they are all technically identical) 

While crucible is usable in this state, the effect of this is that JIRA does not see the code review to changeset association and therefore the "Unreviewed changesets" workflow condition evaluates to false and NOT true

Literally - in the source tab of an issue that has code in a review, the crucible review key does not show up next to the changeset.  The reviews do show up in the review tab.  At the same time, the crucible source view has this:  The repository 'xxxxx-svn' is being scanned, information from the repository may not be up to date (Status message: Indexing review data.).

i wonder if this should be filed as a but - but will start with a support request.

what steps can we take to alleviate this in the short term?
fields.summary: For some svn repos, crucible will be 'stuck' indexing review data for days - and JIRA won't accurately evaluate workflow conditions as a result

fields.description: In our TPM image we only have access to one database called XE so we need to use multiple usernames/passwords instead of different SIDs.
fields.summary: Make Oracle multidb tests support testing of upgrades

fields.description:
As anonymous user, clicking the recently visited dropdown twice will cause the dropdown to lock and hovering over other dropdowns will not appear when moused over

As a logged in user, clicking the dropdown the second time will toggle it off

http://screencast.com/t/aRYWQiFlM
fields.summary: Recently visited dropdowns lock when user is anonymous

fields.description:
Several things:
# The only way to click through to a review feed (even before this bug) was via the feed item's url.  There should be a link inside the content of the feed item.
# Thunderbird can't/doesn't calculate the url for the feed Item, so you still need to use fully qualified urls to be able to click through to the Review, this is what has been broken recently.
# I believe you should be able to click through the the change set as well, this currently doesn't work, but I am assuming its due to the same problem in #2

This issue existed (and has already been fixed) for the change set rss items as well.

Example:

https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/cru/rssReviewFilter?state=Review&state=Open%20Snippet&orRoles=false&project=CR-BAM&filter=custom
!https://img.skitch.com/20110209-run3gjb67nrxygu847wj8gnsk1.jpg!
fields.summary: Review rss feed provides no way to navigate to review in thunderbird

fields.description:
1. Go to {{Administration - > Security Settings -> Authentication}}.
2. Choose the {{Edit}} link for any repository.

Error in the screenshot is shown.
fields.summary: Cannot Edit Per-Repository Authentication Settings

fields.description:
I'm trying to restore a 2.4.4 backup into 2.5.0 using Oracle and I keep getting the following error:

{noformat}
Creating table definitions...
java.io.IOException: Error talking to database: Problem opening create tables script
	at com.atlassian.crucible.migration.item.SQLBackup.restore(SQLBackup.java:205)
	at com.atlassian.crucible.migration.item.SQLBackup$1.restore(SQLBackup.java:172)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.ctl.Restore.run(Restore.java:159)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.ctl.Restore.main(Restore.java:228)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:597)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.FishEyeCtl.mainImpl(FishEyeCtl.java:113)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.FishEyeCtl.main(FishEyeCtl.java:41)
Caused by: com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.CruDBException: Problem opening create tables script
	at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.DefaultDBControl.createTables(DefaultDBControl.java:279)
	at com.atlassian.crucible.migration.item.DBImporter.importData(DBImporter.java:127)
	at com.atlassian.crucible.migration.item.SQLBackup.restore(SQLBackup.java:191)
	... 9 more
Caused by: java.io.FileNotFoundException: /usr/local/fecru/fecru-2.5.0/sql/ORACLE/schema/tables_69.sql (No such file or directory)
	at java.io.FileInputStream.open(Native Method)
	at java.io.FileInputStream.<init>(FileInputStream.java:106)

	at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.DefaultDBControl.createTables(DefaultDBControl.java:274)

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a backup (without cache) in Crucible 2.4.4.
2. Shut down Crucible 2.4.4.
3. Install Crucible 2.5.0.
4. Try running the restore from the command line:
{noformat}./fisheyectl.sh restore --file /usr/local/fecru/fecru-2.4.4/backup/backup_2011-08-02_0903.zip --dbtype oracle --jdbcurl jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/XE --username crucible --password crucible{noformat}

fields.description:
While we can exclude files from indexing based on their size, we can't exclude them from being diffed. This can cause OOMEs.

We should check for the size of the files and produce the diffs per file rather than per changeset if necessary. See https://support.atlassian.com/browse/FSH-5160
fields.summary: Very large text files produce OOME when diffing

fields.description: Would like to make Crucible the standard commercial code review tool within my company, but users of Code Collaborator need support for non-text document reviews (PDF and images are most common; see http://smartbear.com/docs/manual/6.0/index.html). Add support for these file types to Crucible.

fields.description:
This is due to QueryParser being used.
The exception only appears in the server logs.

Two things to fix:
# log this error at debug (or info). 
# strip trailing colons from search queries.

The search is not affected however, since we catch the exception and create our own query.

fields.description:
I add an app link to a crucible only instance from JIRA. However, in JIRA the fisheye link is configured with "Enable Crucible Integration" set to "yes" (i.e. it thinks it connected to a Fisheye server). This means that no reviews will show up until the user sets "Enable Crucible Integration" to "Standalone". There is no indication that the user must do this.

It looks like we are making a call to the "Crucible" server to find its type, however, the server is returning an error (FishEyeInstanceManagerImpl:~203). In this case the plugin assumes a setting of "yes". 

The projects in my Crucible instance are only visible to logged in users. Not sure if this has any bearing on the outcome.
fields.summary: Adding an AppLink to a "standalone Crucible" creates a FishEye configuration that is unusable.
Quotes in "Objectives" text are turned into &#XXX;

fields.description:
# In JIRA Configure a trusted app + app link between Crucible and JIRA. You will need shared users between JIRA and CRU.
# Make sure no crucible projects are mapped (i.e. there should be no JIRA project -> CRU projects app links anywhere)
# Make sure "Disable for unmapped JIRA Projects" is off.
# Make sure the crucible projects are not accessible to anonymous users (i.e. if you goto the CRU project page as anon you should see nothing). You need to have a project accesible to logged in users.
# Goto an issue in JIRA. You should have a "reviews" tab (there may be nothing in it)
# Restart JIRA.
# (DEFECT) Goto the same issue as before. Notice you have no review tab.
# Goto "FishEye Config" in Jira's admin section. 
# Click refresh a few times.
# Goto the same issue as before. Notice that you have a review tab again.

When we restart the JIRA server the lookup the CRU projects available on CRU. JIRA uses this list as a list of CRU projects to search when there is no mapping from the JIRA project to a CRU project. However, when the server is starting there is no user and as such JIRA tries to access CRU anonymously and will think there is no projects.

This does not seem to happen in 4.2.3.

This may also be a problem for FISH repos and well as CRU projects.
fields.summary: The reviews tab may not display after a JIRA server restart if the crucible projects require logged in users + trusted apps configured for authentication + no direct project mapping

fields.description:
EditRevisionsAjaxAction can potentially cause an app-database deadlock. This has been observed in both Oracle and PostgreSQL. Because the lock is cross-domain, databases will not detect the deadlock. The deadlock will prevent all subsequent review creation, and require the instance to be restarted.

Ironically HSQLDB is immune from this bug because it serialises requests.

Support case: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CRC-2172
fields.summary: database level deadlock in EditRevisionsAjaxAction

fields.description:
If a file is submitted via the xml REST api that contains xml keywords that are parsed by the REST interface, you may receive a 400 error from the server.

Specifically, this line was found to cause a failure when using the addPatch API.


    data = "<addPatch><repository>{0}</repository><patch><![CDATA[{1}]]></patch></addPatch>".format(tag, filedata)


This was a difficult issue to debug as there is no information that comes back with a 400 error. Please consider improving this when fixing this bug.

The new emails show you the thread of reviews comments which is great but they are backwards to wahts sueful.

Most email threading is done with most recent first so that you read from top to bottom going backwards in time.

But this crucible emails are the wrong way around.

For example Jed said this first, followed by Darius.  I get two emails but its tricky to work out whats going on and you have to scroll to the bottom and read upwards

Jed :

File: jira/trunk/jira-components/jira-tests/src/test/java/com/atlassian/jira/issue/index/TestDefaultIndexManagerConcurrentIndexing.java

Comment by Jed Wesley-Smith (the real one) on 24 January 2011, 20:03 
https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/cru/CR-JRA-417/#c40911

  To really, really test this, supply an IssueIndexer that blocks
  inside optimize() and repeatedly call reindex(). This provably
  reproduces the error condition. The current test relies on
  fortune to reproduce the initial conditions for the race
  condition.

  Reply by Dariusz Kordonski on 25 January 2011, 00:05
   > I simulate work in optimize() by doing a Thread.sleep().
   > Indexing has sleep of 500ms, optimizing 2000ms (after the
   > fix). It's all in {{MockIssueIndexer}}. Do you think it's
   > good enough?

    #> Not for a unit-test. You need to have a latch pair that
    #> co-ordinates the threads so that you know the states.
    #> Otherwise you have a test that (a) is flaky and (b) is
    #> slow.

      #> All right, I would argue that it is not flaky, but

        #> particularly likely is not evidence of its
        #> non-flakiness :-)

fields.description: Both crucible comment search (ie [CONTEXT/cru/commentSearch|https://extranet.atlassian.com/crucible/cru/commentSearch]) and general search (ie [CONTEXT/cru/search|https://extranet.atlassian.com/crucible/cru/search]) have permission checking incorporated into the hibernate query, but the way they do it can exclude valid results.  They generate a list of projects that the user can see and restrict the search results to those projects, but that ignores permissions schemes which also allow viewing by role --- for example, if a person can't normally view a project but if they're added as a reviewer to a review in that project they can see that review.

       at org.hibernate.impl.QueryImpl.iterate(QueryImpl.java:69)
       at com.cenqua.crucible.model.managers.impl.DefaultReviewManager.anyReviewsConsideredInStateContainingFileRevision(DefaultReviewManager.java:721)
       at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.impl.ReviewInfoDAO.processRevision(ReviewInfoDAO.java:283)
       at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.impl.ReviewInfoDAO.doIncremental(ReviewInfoDAO.java:155)
       ... 12 more
Caused by: java.sql.SQLException: ORA-01000: maximum open cursors exceeded
       at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.impl.ReviewInfoDAO.doIncremental(ReviewInfoDAO.java:165)
{code}
Note the position of the exception in ReviewInfoDAO.java:

{code}
            boolean inReview = reviewManager.isConsideredInReview(fr, reviewId);
            boolean isClosed = reviewManager.anyReviewsConsideredInStateContainingFileRevision(closedStates, fr);
--->        boolean isOpen = reviewManager.anyReviewsConsideredInStateContainingFileRevision(openStates, fr);
            boolean isDraft = reviewManager.anyReviewsConsideredInStateContainingFileRevision(draftStates, fr);
{code}

So an un-closed iterate from the first call to reviewManager.anyReviewsConsideredInStateContainingFileRevision() may be causing the cursor count to be exceeded in the second call.
fields.summary: "ORA-01000: maximum open cursors exceeded" during incremental review indexing

fields.description:
The current project drop down list to select from when creating a new review (very first step), is limited to 50 items for performance reasons. However, we have many more than 50 projects, and our users get confused by not seeing they're project in the list. Auto-completion still works so if they happen to know the key of they're project they can just start typing it and continue. This is very awkward though as we have a large number of projects, and not everyone has every project memorized!

Please change the brute force approach of 50 item limit, to being a contextual scoping; show only the projects that the user is in some way associated with. For example they have previously made commits to, reviews to, or are in a group that is tied to the project or repository,

This contextual scoping will be much more appropriate and likely a lot less than 50 items. For cases where its not possible to auto-detect the context of the user, there should be a list all check box, which fills the drop down list with _all_ projects. They clicked it, they asked for it, its ok to wait.
fields.summary: Review Creation Project Drop Down List Should be Contextual

fields.description: When migrating to a new database, the user is invited to "test connection". Once a test has been successful, two options are enabled: "Save", and "Save & Migrate". If the user selects "Save", the configuration is saved, and no migration occurs. There is then no way to re-enable the "save & migrate" button, meaning no migration can happen. The user is at a loss at this point.
fields.summary: [Admin] "Save & Migrate" is never re-enabled

fields.description: Walks user through creating database, user etc, but not the actual data migration. See MySQL Migration guide for example.
fields.summary: Documentation on migration to PSQL leaves user hanging

fields.description:
After running {{create database crucible ENCODING 'UTF-8' ...}} on PSQL8.0, {{show server_encoding}} reports {{"UNICODE"}}. Our code checks for the string {{"UTF8"}}, so won't allow a connection.

PSQL8.1 returns {{"UTF8"}} as the code expects, meaning this is the actual minimum version supported. We should update the SPM accordingly.
fields.summary: SPM lists PSQL8.0 as minimum supported, but in fact it is PSQL8.1
